name: 2'-hydroxy-5'-methylacetophenone
Reason: Starting with the basic unit, benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C, various functional groups will affect this. A methyl group generally increases the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces; this effect can be estimated as +15°C. The hydroxyl (-OH) group can form hydrogen bonds, which generally increases the melting point considerably, estimated as +40°C. The carbonyl group (C=O) in acetophenone usually increases the melting point due to its ability to accept hydrogen bonds and due to dipole-dipole interactions. The electron-withdrawing effect of the carbonyl group also stabilizes the molecule and contributes an additional +30°C. However, steric hindrance can impede effective hydrogen bonding, which may lead to a less pronounced effect from the hydroxyl group; therefore, we might need to reduce its contribution slightly by about -10°C. Combining these effects while also considering that the compound as a whole has a melting point of 47.0°C, the contributions need to be adjusted to reflect this actual value.

The methyl group (CH3) attached to the acetophenone (phenyl with a carbonyl group) increases the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at +5°C.
